thread.title_full: Free-range eggs crisis prevented as Government finally agrees farmers can let chickens outside

author: Katie Morley
title: Free-range eggs crisis prevented as Government finally agrees farmers can let chickens outside

organizations.name: department for food and rural affairs
department for environment, food and rural affairs

text:
A looming free-range egg crisis has been prevented just in the nick of time as the Government has said farmers can finally let chickens outside at the end of the month.
On Feb 28 the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs will partially lift a housing order which has seen millions of chickens cooped up in barns for three months.
Around 80pc of poultry farms will be allowed to let chickens outside while the remaining 20pc which are deemed to be in "high risk" areas will still have to keep poultry inside. 
Under EU law eggs and meat which usually qualify for free range status must be sold as "barn" or "caged" if they have been inside for 12 weeks or more. 
It means that farms who let poultry outside from Feb 28 will narrowly keep their free-range status.
Birds which remain inside will no longer be classed as free-range, with their meat and eggs being re-labelled for sale as "barn", which can be up to a fifth cheaper to buy.
Poultry has not been allowed to roam free outside for nearly three months Credit: Steve Smailes Photography A round half of the eggs sold in supermarkets are British free-range, while some 5pc of chickens are free range, according to the Department for Food and Rural Affairs.
Stickers have already started to appear on boxes of free range eggs announcing that the hens that laid the eggs have been kept, temporarily, in barns "for their welfare". 
Defra said the risk of disease across the country remains high and measures are likely to be in place until at least the end of April. According to Public Health England the risk to public health is very low and the Food Standards Agency has said there is no food safety risk for consumers.
Chief Veterinary Officer Nigel Gibbens said: “Effective disease control will always be our priority. H5N8 continues to circulate in wild birds and we must all continue to do everything we can to reduce the risk of disease. All keepers across the country must follow strict mandatory disease prevention measures.
“Based on clear scientific evidence, the risk from wild birds is too high in some areas of England to rely on biosecurity measures alone. That’s why we are requiring birds in Higher Risk Areas to be housed or protected from wild bird contact by netting.
“We believe this is the best approach to control disease, protect birds’ welfare and ensure consumers can buy free range products. As with any disease control measures these will be kept under review based on the latest situation and up-to-date scientific advice.”
